summary: Brie Larson talks suiting up as the 'flawed' but 'empowering' hero in 'Captain Marvel'
title: Brie Larson talks suiting up as the 'flawed' but 'empowering' hero in 'Captain Marvel'
excerpt: The Oscar winner opens up about why she hesitated to take the role, and how training to play Carol Danvers uncovered her inner Keanu Reeves
description:
When Brie Larson talks about Captain Marvel, the word that comes up over and over again is “flaw.”

Carol Danvers — the Air Force pilot with alien powers that Larson plays in Captain Marvel — is very flawed. She may be a part-Kree, part-human warrior with the powers of a god, but she’s anything but godlike: She’s aggressive and brash, impulsive and hotheaded. She’s the first one to rush into battle, and she doesn’t always wait for orders. She tells bad jokes. And in many ways, Captain Marvel (out March 2019) finds her at war with herself, as she tries to reconcile her Kree perfectionism with her human fallibility.

“You have this Kree part of her that’s unemotional, that is an amazing fighter and competitive,” Larson says. “Then there’s this human part of her that is flawed but is also the thing that she ends up leading by. It’s the thing that gets her in trouble, but it’s also the thing that makes her great. And those two sides warring against each other is what makes her her.”

Carol’s flaws are what drive her story, and it’s those same flaws that drew Larson — an Oscar winner best known for dramas like Room and Short Term 12 — to Captain Marvel. There are the action scenes and wisecracks and bright-green aliens that come with most Marvel movies, of course, but there are also moments of introspection: When the film starts, Carol has left Earth behind to adventure in the stars and join the elite Kree military team Starforce, but she soon finds herself back on her home planet with new questions about her past and identity.

“That is something that is really exciting to me about this film: We did not cut corners on that stuff,” Larson says. “Like, when it’s funny, it is funny, but also when there’s deep emotional things happening, it’s real. So I was able to bring some of those same things that I’ve brought to full dramatic roles into this, which I’m really proud of because I think it will really set this film apart.”

Still, Larson didn’t immediately say yes. Marvel first approached her about the role several years ago, and she was intrigued but hesitant to come aboard. “I never saw myself doing something like this, mostly because I like being anonymous,” she says. “I like disappearing into characters, and I always felt like if I was out in the public eye too much, it potentially limits you in the future.”

She took several months to officially sign on, but she was ultimately swayed by the chance to bring such a complex, dramatic character into a blockbuster franchise.

“Just seeing a character who says how she feels and says what’s on her mind and doesn’t let people stand in her way is incredibly empowering,” Larson says. And becoming the face of a Marvel superhero doesn’t hurt, either: The first time she put on the Captain Marvel suit, she says, her first thought was, “Whoa, am I going to be a character at Disneyland?”

She just might — and it’d be a milestone that would only continue her history of heroics both on screen and off, something Marvel had been looking for when searching for the right actor to play their first big-screen solo female hero. Not only did Larson win a Best Actress Oscar for 2015’s Room, but she’s also emerged as a feminist advocate and voice during the #MeToo movement. “She’s already an inspiration to many in her real-world work, and now we get to put her in an iconic costume and give her these powers on the big screen,” says Marvel Studios president Kevin Feige.

“She has a sense of determination that fits this character very well,” adds Samuel L. Jackson, who starred alongside Larson in Kong: Skull Island and reprises his role as Nick Fury in Captain Marvel. “It’s a lot of work to get ready for something like this, and she did all that. She’s got the talent and the skill to make it something that’s going to be very special.”

To prepare, Larson immersed herself in Captain Marvel comics, particularly the recent series written by Kelly Sue DeConnick, where Carol officially took over the Captain Marvel mantle. She also met and trained with real Air Force pilots, even going up for a flight in an F-16.

And on set, she’s tried to imbue the film with a sense of camaraderie and joy. (She started a tradition of handing out different pin-back buttons to the cast and crew every week, each one with a different Captain Marvel image, ’90s reference, or inside joke.)

“There are certain people that are made for this, and she’s definitely one of them,” says Lashana Lynch, who plays Carol’s Air Force cohort Maria Rambeau. “She’s carefree, she’s disciplined, she creates a very cohesive environment. The whole crew are as tight as they are because of her. She brings in games to work. We’ve got like a karaoke machine somewhere on the lot that I’ve not used, but I know that we’re gonna use at some point.”

And then there’s the training. The role requires emotional heavy lifting, but there’s physical heavy lifting, too: Feige confirms that Captain Marvel is the most powerful hero the MCU has ever seen, and Larson started training nine months before filming began, learning judo, boxing, and even some wrestling. (Her pump-up playlist includes plenty of appropriately ’90s riot grrrl staples like Bikini Kill, Bratmobile, and L7.)

“I was an introvert with asthma before this movie,” she says with a laugh. “I really thought when they hired me, ‘I am the worst choice for an action movie.’ And I didn’t know that I had a little Keanu Reeves in me! Who knew?”

And once she’s conquered Marvel, she’s already got her eye on her next goal.

“I’ve been joking that I’m going to go to the 2020 Olympics [for judo],” Larson says. “What’s funny is I’ve been saying it the last couple of weeks, and people are like, ‘Ahhhh,’ like they can’t tell if I’m serious or not. And honestly, I can’t tell if I’m serious or not! I’m really not. But now when I’m getting scripts of what to do next, I’m like, this has to be better than the Olympics. My bar is the Olympics. It’s a pretty high bar.”

So basically Brie Larson is gonna kill it and Captain Marvel is gonna crush Thanos and we’re all gonna be in love?? Cool cool cool…

So basically Brie Larson is gonna kill it and Captain Marvel is gonna crush Thanos and we’re all gonna be in love?? Cool cool cool…

summary: YOU  WANNA READ CAPTAIN MARVEL COMICS BECAUSE THERE’S A HELLAH COOL MOVIE  COMING OUT? LET’S GO!
title: YOU  WANNA READ CAPTAIN MARVEL COMICS BECAUSE THERE’S A HELLAH COOL MOVIE  COMING OUT? LET’S GO!
body:
OKAY GUYS, WHAT UPPPPP. You wanna read Captain Marvel comics?? You saw Brie Larson looking FUCKING 90S RAD in that EW spread? Actually hey let’s just take a moment and enjoy that again for all of our sake’s.

I have already bought a grey hat and that SHIELD patch MY FRIENDS okay.

SO! Here’s your official How-To Guide to read Captain Marvel (Carol Danvers) comics! Before the cut is your JUST NAMES AND NUMBERS list. After the cut are short explanations and cover images!

Carol as Captain Marvel (chronologically!)

  • Captain Marvel (2011-2013) Issues #1-17
  • Captain Marvel (2013-2015) Issues #1-15
  • Captain Marvel and the Carol Corps (2015) Issues #1-4
  • Captain Marvel (2016) Issues #1-10
  • Civil War II
  • The Mighty Captain Marvel (2017) Issues #0-9, #125-130
  • The Life of Captain Marvel (2018) Issues #1-5
  • Captain Marvel (2019) Issues #1-ongoing!

Carol from the start

  • Marvel Super-Heroes #13
  • Ms. Marvel (1977-1979) #1-23
  • Ms. Marvel (2006-2010) #1-50

Need more detail??! Confused??! OKAY THEN HERE WE GO.

CAROL TAKES THE DAMN NAME

The first book where Carol got her Captain Marvel title was Captain Marvel (2012-2013). See, Carol Danvers first appeared in Marvel Superheroes Issue #13. There was this hero, Captain Marvel, aka Mar-vell, a Kree warrior (AKA, an alien dude). Through a series of ridiculous comic book events, Carol ends up getting his powers. This launches her first solo series, “Ms. Marvel”, back in 1977! I’ll talk about that at the end. But basically, Mar-vell died back in the 80s or so, the name has been passed around a bunch, and then in 2011 Carol finally took the name of her mentor/guy who gave her her powers, and thus launched Carol Danvers’ CAPTAIN MARVEL series, with the very excellent @kellysue at the helm and Dexter Soy on art.

This run was 17 issues long. You can buy the individual issues through the digital comic shop, Amazon, actual comic shops, &c. You can also buy it in collected editions. The first collected edition is “In Pursuit of Flight”. This collects issues 1-6. The second collected edition is “Down”, and collects issues 7-12.

Issues #13 and #14 are actually part of a cross-over event with another book Kelly Sue was writing at the time, “Avengers Assemble.” The cross-over event was called “The Enemy Within” and was all about Carol. You can buy those 2 issues (13 and 14) as well as the first issue of the story arc, “Avengers: The Enemy Within”, 2 issues of Avengers Assemble (16, 17), and issue 17 (the last issue) of Captain Marvel as a collected edition.

Captain Marvel issues #15 and #16 are cross-overs with the Avengers Infinity event, and can only be bought as single-issues, as far as I know.

So that rounds out the first run of Captain Marvel for Carol Danvers!

CAPTAIN MARVEL HIGHER FASTER FURTHER MORE!!!

The next run of Captain Marvel was 2014-2015, still by Kelly Sue with David Lopez on art! It was 15 issues long! Issues 1-6 are collected in the volume “Higher, Further, Faster, More” . 

The next volume collects issues 7-11 and is called “Stay Fly”:

The next volume collects issues 12-15 and is called “Alis Volat Propriis”:

And that wraps up that run of Captain Marvel comics, 2014-2015! BUT FEAR NOT, there was one last mini series that the INCOMPARABLE Kelly Sue penned, once again with David Lopez.

ALTERNATE UNIVERSE SHENANIGANS??! 

So then in 2015 this BIIIIIG event happened at Marvel called “Secret Wars.” Basically all YOU, the curious Carol Danvers newbie, need to know is that it temporarily resulted in a patchwork universe made up of lots of different alternate universes (SURE). One of those alternate universes was explored in this FINAL SEND-OFF FOUR ISSUE MINI by Kelly Sue called Captain Marvel and the Carol Corps. Collected volume here digital issues here.

A NEW ERA… AGAIN!

The next run was Captain Marvel 2016, Issues #1-10. There were a lot of different writers on this run–Fazekas, Butters, Guggenheim, Gage–with @kristaferanka​ as the main artist. The first collected volume is issues 1-5, “Rise of Alpha Flight”!

The second collected volume of that is just called “Captain Marvel: Civil War II” and collects issues 6-10 of this 2016 run. And that’s it for the 2016 run!

Then Civil War II happened and Carol was involved with that (it was Carol Danvers vs Tony Stark, that was the “Civil War”) and… I’m not a fan, so here’s the collected volume, do with that what you will!

EARTH’S MIGHTIEST HERO

After Civil War II, the Captain Marvel series once again relaunched, this time retitled “The Mighty Captain Marvel.” This series ran from 2016-2017, penned by Margaret Stohl and art by Ramon Rosanas. WEIRD NOTE: The series started out  “The Mighty Captain Marvel” Issues #0-9. THEN, it switched to “legacy” numbering (don’t even ASK) and continued issues #125-130. THAT’S RIGHT: After “The Might Captain Marvel” Issue #9, you have to pick up “The Mighty Captain Marvel” issue #125. Don’t. Even. ASK.

The collected volumes are “Alien Nation” Issues #0-4

Followed by the 2nd collected volume of that run, “Band of Sisters”, which collects #5-9

And then Vol 3, the last collection of the “The Mighty Captain Marvel” run, is called “Dark Origins” and collects issues #125-130 (YES, I KNOW, THE NUMBERING IS SO STUPID)

NO REST FOR THE MIGHTY

Carol took a little break and recuperating and reconnecting with her roots in the mini-series LIFE OF CAPTAIN MARVEL, written by again Margaret Stohl, art by Pacheco. That series was 5 issues long and is now officially in a collected volume!

CURRENT RUN

FINALLY, Wanna read CURRENT CAPTAIN MARVEL COMICS? Like ones that are coming out RIGHT NOW? The current run of Captain Marvel comics just started in time for the new movie, Captain Marvel (2019) by Kelly Thompson and Carmen Carnero! So if you just wanna be able to walk into a comic shop and start reading current Captain Marvel comics, you can start with that!



WAIT WHAT ABOUT THAT MS MARVEL 70S ACTION???

If you want OLD school Carol Danvers, you’ll have to look to her MS Marvel series’. There’s Ms. Marvel (1977-1979). I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT. It’s great fun and very in-your-face feminism and there’s lots of lady relationships, both good and bad, throughout the short series.

It ran 23 issues long. The CLZ app will SAY it ran 25 issues, but the last 2 issues it’s referring to are ACTUALLY “Marvel Super-Heroes Vol 2” issues 10 and 11. They were old issue ideas that were intended for the original series but when it got canceled they got scraped, basically, and then finished up and released when they needed some filler stuff in the early 90s. They’re great issues, totally in-tone with the original series, and I recommend grabbing them if you can.

The second volume was Ms. Marvel (2006-2010) which was 50 issues long. I recommend this one… less.

It’s available in 9 different collected editions w various cross-over events.

The LATEST Ms. Marvel (2014-2015) isn’t actually Carol at all, but a brand-new superhero: Kamala Khan. She’s basically the most adorable thing ever and I HIGHLY recommend checking out her new series. She has TWO different series, Ms. Marvel 2014-2015 which was 19 issues long; and Ms. Marvel 2015-present which has 37 issues out so far! Those also have lots of collected editions starting with “No Normal”. 

I’M CONFUSED. JUST TELL ME WHAT TO READ.

If you want to start reading Carol, I recommend picking up either the first collected edition of Captain Marvel (2012-2013) (that’s “In Pursuit of Flight”) or the first collected edition of Captain Marvel (2014-) (“Higher, Further, Faster, More”). Both of those are excellent starting points, since they’re the start of their respective series. Alternatively, grab the single issues (you can buy them all at the Marvel digital comic shop), start from number 1, and just read forward. Many libraries also carry collected editions of comics, so if you’re strapped for cash you may have some luck there!

TL;DR, ONE MORE TIME:

Carol as Captain Marvel (chronologically!)

  • Captain Marvel (2011-2013) Issues #1-17
  • Captain Marvel (2013-2015) Issues #1-15
  • Captain Marvel and the Carol Corps (2015) Issues #1-4
  • Captain Marvel (2016) Issues #1-10
  • Civil War II
  • The Mighty Captain Marvel (2017) Issues #0-9, 125-130
  • The Life of Captain Marvel (2018) Issues #1-5
  • Captain Marvel (2019) Issues #1-ongoing

Carol from the start

  • Marvel Super-Heroes #13
  • Ms. Marvel (1977-1979) #1-23
  • Ms. Marvel (2006-2010) #1-50

The first book where Carol got her Captain Marvel title was Captain Marvel (2012-2013). See, Carol Danvers first appeared in Marvel Superheroes Issue #13. There was this hero, Captain Marvel, aka Mar-vell, a Kree warrior (AKA, an alien dude). Through a series of ridiculous comic book events, Carol ends up getting his powers. This launches her first solo series, “Ms. Marvel”, back in 1977! I’ll talk about that at the end. But basically, Mar-vell died back in the 80s or so, the name has been passed around a bunch, and then in 2011 Carol finally took the name of her mentor/guy who gave her her powers, and thus launched Carol Danvers’ CAPTAIN MARVEL series, with the very excellent @kellysue at the helm and Dexter Soy on art.

This run was 17 issues long. You can buy the individual issues through the digital comic shop, Amazon, actual comic shops, &c. You can also buy it in collected editions. The first collected edition is “In Pursuit of Flight”. This collects issues 1-6. The second collected edition is “Down”, and collects issues 7-12.

Issues #13 and #14 are actually part of a cross-over event with another book Kelly Sue was writing at the time, “Avengers Assemble.” The cross-over event was called “The Enemy Within” and was all about Carol. You can buy those 2 issues (13 and 14) as well as the first issue of the story arc, “Avengers: The Enemy Within”, 2 issues of Avengers Assemble (16, 17), and issue 17 (the last issue) of Captain Marvel as a collected edition.

Captain Marvel issues #15 and #16 are cross-overs with the Avengers Infinity event, and can only be bought as single-issues, as far as I know.

So that rounds out the first run of Captain Marvel for Carol Danvers!

CAPTAIN MARVEL HIGHER FASTER FURTHER MORE!!!

The next run of Captain Marvel was 2014-2015, still by Kelly Sue with David Lopez on art! It was 15 issues long! Issues 1-6 are collected in the volume “Higher, Further, Faster, More” . 

The next volume collects issues 7-11 and is called “Stay Fly”:

The next volume collects issues 12-15 and is called “Alis Volat Propriis”:

And that wraps up that run of Captain Marvel comics, 2014-2015! BUT FEAR NOT, there was one last mini series that the INCOMPARABLE Kelly Sue penned, once again with David Lopez.

ALTERNATE UNIVERSE SHENANIGANS??! 

So then in 2015 this BIIIIIG event happened at Marvel called “Secret Wars.” Basically all YOU, the curious Carol Danvers newbie, need to know is that it temporarily resulted in a patchwork universe made up of lots of different alternate universes (SURE). One of those alternate universes was explored in this FINAL SEND-OFF FOUR ISSUE MINI by Kelly Sue called Captain Marvel and the Carol Corps. Collected volume here digital issues here.

A NEW ERA… AGAIN!

The next run was Captain Marvel 2016, Issues #1-10. There were a lot of different writers on this run–Fazekas, Butters, Guggenheim, Gage–with @kristaferanka​ as the main artist. The first collected volume is issues 1-5, “Rise of Alpha Flight”!

The second collected volume of that is just called “Captain Marvel: Civil War II” and collects issues 6-10 of this 2016 run. And that’s it for the 2016 run!

Then Civil War II happened and Carol was involved with that (it was Carol Danvers vs Tony Stark, that was the “Civil War”) and… I’m not a fan, so here’s the collected volume, do with that what you will!

EARTH’S MIGHTIEST HERO

After Civil War II, the Captain Marvel series once again relaunched, this time retitled “The Mighty Captain Marvel.” This series ran from 2016-2017, penned by Margaret Stohl and art by Ramon Rosanas. WEIRD NOTE: The series started out  “The Mighty Captain Marvel” Issues #0-9. THEN, it switched to “legacy” numbering (don’t even ASK) and continued issues #125-130. THAT’S RIGHT: After “The Might Captain Marvel” Issue #9, you have to pick up “The Mighty Captain Marvel” issue #125. Don’t. Even. ASK.

The collected volumes are “Alien Nation” Issues #0-4

Followed by the 2nd collected volume of that run, “Band of Sisters”, which collects #5-9

And then Vol 3, the last collection of the “The Mighty Captain Marvel” run, is called “Dark Origins” and collects issues #125-130 (YES, I KNOW, THE NUMBERING IS SO STUPID)

NO REST FOR THE MIGHTY

Carol took a little break and recuperating and reconnecting with her roots in the mini-series LIFE OF CAPTAIN MARVEL, written by again Margaret Stohl, art by Pacheco. That series was 5 issues long and is now officially in a collected volume!

CURRENT RUN

FINALLY, Wanna read CURRENT CAPTAIN MARVEL COMICS? Like ones that are coming out RIGHT NOW? The current run of Captain Marvel comics just started in time for the new movie, Captain Marvel (2019) by Kelly Thompson and Carmen Carnero! So if you just wanna be able to walk into a comic shop and start reading current Captain Marvel comics, you can start with that!



WAIT WHAT ABOUT THAT MS MARVEL 70S ACTION???

If you want OLD school Carol Danvers, you’ll have to look to her MS Marvel series’. There’s Ms. Marvel (1977-1979). I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT. It’s great fun and very in-your-face feminism and there’s lots of lady relationships, both good and bad, throughout the short series.

It ran 23 issues long. The CLZ app will SAY it ran 25 issues, but the last 2 issues it’s referring to are ACTUALLY “Marvel Super-Heroes Vol 2” issues 10 and 11. They were old issue ideas that were intended for the original series but when it got canceled they got scraped, basically, and then finished up and released when they needed some filler stuff in the early 90s. They’re great issues, totally in-tone with the original series, and I recommend grabbing them if you can.

The second volume was Ms. Marvel (2006-2010) which was 50 issues long. I recommend this one… less.

It’s available in 9 different collected editions w various cross-over events.

The LATEST Ms. Marvel (2014-2015) isn’t actually Carol at all, but a brand-new superhero: Kamala Khan. She’s basically the most adorable thing ever and I HIGHLY recommend checking out her new series. She has TWO different series, Ms. Marvel 2014-2015 which was 19 issues long; and Ms. Marvel 2015-present which has 37 issues out so far! Those also have lots of collected editions starting with “No Normal”. 

I’M CONFUSED. JUST TELL ME WHAT TO READ.

If you want to start reading Carol, I recommend picking up either the first collected edition of Captain Marvel (2012-2013) (that’s “In Pursuit of Flight”) or the first collected edition of Captain Marvel (2014-) (“Higher, Further, Faster, More”). Both of those are excellent starting points, since they’re the start of their respective series. Alternatively, grab the single issues (you can buy them all at the Marvel digital comic shop), start from number 1, and just read forward. Many libraries also carry collected editions of comics, so if you’re strapped for cash you may have some luck there!

TL;DR, ONE MORE TIME:

Carol as Captain Marvel (chronologically!)

  • Captain Marvel (2011-2013) Issues #1-17
  • Captain Marvel (2013-2015) Issues #1-15
  • Captain Marvel and the Carol Corps (2015) Issues #1-4
  • Captain Marvel (2016) Issues #1-10
  • Civil War II
  • The Mighty Captain Marvel (2017) Issues #0-9, 125-130
  • The Life of Captain Marvel (2018) Issues #1-5
  • Captain Marvel (2019) Issues #1-ongoing

Carol from the start

  • Marvel Super-Heroes #13
  • Ms. Marvel (1977-1979) #1-23
  • Ms. Marvel (2006-2010) #1-50
trail.content_abstract:
OKAY GUYS, WHAT UPPPPP. You wanna read Captain Marvel comics?? You saw Brie Larson looking FUCKING 90S RAD in that EW spread? Actually hey let’s just take a moment and enjoy that again for all of our sake’s.

I have already bought a grey hat and that SHIELD patch MY FRIENDS okay.

SO! Here’s your official How-To Guide to read Captain Marvel (Carol Danvers) comics! Before the cut is your JUST NAMES AND NUMBERS list. After the cut are short explanations and cover images!

Carol as Captain Marvel (chronologically!)

  • Captain Marvel (2011-2013) Issues #1-17
  • Captain Marvel (2013-2015) Issues #1-15
  • Captain Marvel and the Carol Corps (2015) Issues #1-4
  • Captain Marvel (2016) Issues #1-10
  • Civil War II
  • The Mighty Captain Marvel (2017) Issues #0-9, #125-130
  • The Life of Captain Marvel (2018) Issues #1-5
  • Captain Marvel (2019) Issues #1-ongoing!

Carol from the start

  • Marvel Super-Heroes #13
  • Ms. Marvel (1977-1979) #1-23
  • Ms. Marvel (2006-2010) #1-50

Need more detail??! Confused??! OKAY THEN HERE WE GO.

CAROL TAKES THE DAMN NAME
